body_text.text: Although many leading organizations emphasize individualized glycemic targets and treatment to lower glucose according to specific patient characteristics, the current algorithms of antihyperglycemic therapy in type 2 diabetes are based on treatment modality only considering the fasting and random blood glucose concentration, which are represented by glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), in individual patients [1][2][3] .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: It remains controversial to select first-line drugs to treat diabetic patients, even though metformin is a preferred first-line drug.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In addition, there is no consensus to approach the most effective treatment for an individual patient.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Because most patients have already experienced substantial loss of b-cell function at the time of diagnosis of type 2 diabetes 4,5 , it is more reasonable to select initial antidiabetic medications or modify drugs with consideration for b-cell function of individual patients.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Type 2 diabetes is characterized by insulin resistance and impaired insulin secretion 6 .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although insulin resistance shows little variation among patients with type 2 diabetes, pancreatic b-cell function declines progressively over time.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The United Kingdom Prospective Diabetes Study (UKPDS) and the Belfast Diet Study have shown that progressive loss of b-cell function is a major cause of hyperglycemia and is also related to treatment failure of diabetes 7,8 .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this regard, not only the evaluation of secular changes in insulin secretion, but also accurate methods to evaluate b-cell function are important for management of diabetes 9 .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: C-peptide, which is cleaved from insulin in secretory granules, is a well-known marker for b-cell function 10,11 .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In contrast to other indices for insulin secretion, C-peptide evaluation is able to assess b-cell function even in patients undergoing insulin therapy.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Recently, it was suggested that the C-peptide-to-glucose ratio after oral glucose ingestion might be a better marker for pancreatic b-cell mass than fasting measures, such as the homeostatic model assessment of b-cell function (HOMA-b) 11 .
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus, we investigated the clinical significance of serum postprandial C-peptide-to-glucose ratio (PCGR) measurements in providing indices for insulin secretion and in discriminating treatment modalities for patients with type 2 diabetes.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Patients in the diabetes registry of Severance Diabetes Center between June 2009 and April 2011 were investigated in the present study.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: Type 2 diabetic patients aged older than 20 years were included.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: The exclusion criteria were severe liver or kidney disease, thyroid disorders, pregnancy, glucocorticoid therapy, heavy alcoholics and any malignancy including hematological disorders.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: Our investigation was a retrospective twostep study.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: In the first step, we investigated whether PCGR showed a significant correlation with indices for insulin secretion function, such as HOMA-b, as well as with indices for glycemic control.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: We analyzed 361 newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes patients who were drug-na€ ıve, and had undergone a mixed meal test between June 2009 and April 2011.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: These participants included most of the patients described in our previous study 12 .
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: The test was a standardized liquid meal test (Ensure; Meiji Dairies Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; 500 kcal, 17.5 g fat [31.5%], 68.5 g carbohydrate [54.5%] and 17.5 g protein [14.0%]) after overnight fasting.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: Blood samples were collected at 0 and 90 min (basal and stimulated levels, respectively) for glucose, insulin and C-peptide analyses.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: We used fasting glucose, postprandial glucose, glycated albumin (GA) and HbA1c as the glycemic indices.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: For the insulin secretory indices, we used fasting or postprandial C-peptide (FCP or PCP), delta C-peptide (DCP), fasting C-peptide-to-glucose ratio (FCGR) or PCGR, insulinogenic index (IGI), index for C-peptide (ICI) and HOMA-b.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: In the second step, we assessed the validity of PCGR as a predictor in the choice of antidiabetic therapy.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: For this, we analyzed 558 type 2 diabetic patients who achieved target glycemic control (HbA1c <7.0%), and had constant antidiabetic medication for at least 3 months between November 2009 and April 2011.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: The patients were analyzed retrospectively and divided into four groups according to their treatment modality (group I: exogenous insulin, group II: insulin secretagogues [sulfonylurea (SU) and/or dipeptidyl dipeptidase IV inhibitor (DPPIVi)], group III: insulin sensitizer [metformin (Met) and/ or thiazolidinedione (TZD)], and group IV: lifestyle modification [diet and exercise (D&E)]), based on the treatments' strength and differential function on glycemic reduction.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: We first evaluated whether PCGR levels were significantly different among the groups.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: Subsequently, we investigated the cut-off values of PCGR for discriminating each medication group.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: To evaluate the validity of the cut-off values of PCGR, a training set comprising of randomly selected cases (70% of the participants) was used to select an optimal cut-off, which was then tested on the independent left-out validation set (30% of the participants).
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: The blood samples for plasma glucose and C-peptide were obtained after an overnight fasting and 2 h after an individually composed breakfast.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: The study protocol was approved by the ethics committee of the Severance Hospital.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: According to the International Conference on Harmonization Good Clinical Practice (ICH GCP) guidelines 13 , all information was recorded in a manner so that participants could not be identified and kept in a locked computer.
body_text.section: Patients and Study Design

body_text.text: Plasma glucose levels were measured using the glucose oxidase method and a Hitachi 747 automatic analyzer (Hitachi Instruments Service, Tokyo, Japan).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: Serum GA levels were measured using the enzymatic method and a Hitachi 7699 P module autoanalyzer (Hitachi Instruments Service, Tokyo, Japan).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: HbA1c levels were measured by high-performance liquid chromatography using a Variant II Turbo (Bio-Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA, USA).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: Serum insulin and C-peptide levels were measured in duplicate by immunoradiometric assay (Beckman Coulter, Fullerton, CA, USA).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: DCP was calculated as (C-peptide 90 min -C-peptide 0 min).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: HOMA-b was calculated as fasting insulin (lIU/mL) 9 20 / fasting glucose (mmol/L) -3.5.
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: The IGI was calculated as (insulin 90 mininsulin 0 min) / (glucose 90 minglucose 0 min), while the corresponding ICI was (C-peptide 90 min -C-peptide 0 min) / (glucose 90 minglucose 0 min).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: FCGR and PCGR were calculated as (fasting or postprandial C-peptide level [ng/ mL] / fasting or postprandial glucose level [mg/dL] 9 100).
body_text.section: Biochemical Test

body_text.text: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) or analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) tests was used to compare variables.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: All continuous variables are shown as the mean -standard deviation except for ANCOVA analysis (mean -standard error).
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: To compare the relationship among HbA1c, GA and other variables, Pearson's correlation coefficients were used to assess the associations between clinical and laboratory variables.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: We analyzed the differences in the correlated coefficients between PCGR or HOMA-b and glycemic indices using Steiger's Z-test.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve of PCGR was shown, and the area under the curve (AUC) was calculated for separating each medication group.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: To determine the optimal cut-off value, the point on the ROC curve with maximum Youden index (sensitivity + specificity -1) was calculated.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: Statistical analyses were carried out using SAS version 9.2 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA).
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: A P-value <0.05 was considered significant.
body_text.section: Statistical Analysis

body_text.text: The baseline characteristics of the newly diagnosed type 2 diabetic patients are shown in Table 1.
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: From the first step analysis, the correlation between PCGR and insulin secretory indices widely accepted as predictors for b-cell function was investigated in 361 drug-na€ ıve patients with newly presenting type 2 diabetes ( Table 2).
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: Among these indices, PCP, DCP and PCGR showed a significant correlation with previously established insulin secretory indices, such as IGI, ICI and HOMA-b.
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: The PCGR showed a stronger correlation with HOMA-b (r = 0.552, P < 0.001) than PCP and DCP (r = 0.370, r = 0.307, respectively, all P < 0.001).
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: Although FCGR had a moderately strong correlation (0.6-0.8) with HOMA-b (r = 0.705, P < 0.001), FCGR did not have any correlation with IGI or ICI.
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: As expected, IGI showed a very strong correlation (at least 0.8) with ICI (r = 0.928, P < 0.001).
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: However, neither IGI nor ICI showed any correlation with HOMA-b.
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: A partial correlation adjusted for age, sex and body mass index (BMI) showed similar results among various insulin secretory indices.
body_text.section: Correlations Between Variable Indices of b-Cell Function

body_text.text: During the first step analysis to find an effective insulin secretory index predicting well-controlled glycemia, we compared the correlations of indices for insulin secretion, such as PCGR or HOMA-b, with various glycemic indices, such as fasting and postprandial glucose, glycated albumin and HbA1c.
body_text.section: Correlations of PCGR and HOMA-b with Glycemic Indices

body_text.text: Overall, both indices showed a good correlation with glycemic indices (Figure 1).
body_text.section: Correlations of PCGR and HOMA-b with Glycemic Indices

body_text.text: Although PCGR was calculated using postprandial indices, including C-peptide and glucose level, PCGR (r = -0.558, P < 0.001) showed a strong correlation with fasting glucose levels, which was shown in HOMA-b (r = -0.587, P < 0.001).
body_text.section: Correlations of PCGR and HOMA-b with Glycemic Indices

body_text.text: Additionally, PCGR showed significantly stronger correlations with GA and HbA1c (r = -0.602 with GA and r = -0.591 with HbA1c, all P < 0.001) than HOMA-b did (r = -0.521 with GA, and r = -0.471 with HbA1c, all P < 0.001).
body_text.section: Correlations of PCGR and HOMA-b with Glycemic Indices

body_text.text: In the second step analysis, we hypothesized that the patients who had achieved target glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) might have received appropriate antidiabetic therapy according to their b-cell secretory function.
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: To investigate whether PCGR can differentiate treatment modalities in type 2 diabetes, we analyzed 558 patients with type 2 diabetes under good glycemic control (HbA1c <7%).
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: Table 3 shows the significantly different fasting and postprandial glucose levels among groups that were divided according to treatment modalities.
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: As expected, the insulin-treated group I showed lower C-peptide level (both FCP and PCP) and longer duration of disease than the other medication groups.
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: In contrast to FCGR level, mean PCGR levels were significantly different among groups, and decreased according to the following order: group IV (D&E), group III (Met/TZD), group II (SU/DPPIVi) and group I (insulin; Table 3 and Figure 2).
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: The different PCGR levels among groups were still significant after adjusting for age, sex, BMI and duration of disease (Figure 2).
body_text.section: Clinical Characteristics of Participants According to Antidiabetic Medications

body_text.text: We hypothesized that different types of treatment modalities could be differentiated by PCGR levels in patients with good glycemic control, and determined the cut-off values of PCGR for distinguishing between treatment modalities, such as SU/DPPIVi, Met/TZD and D&E.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: From the training set (70% of the participants), the PCGR cut-off value for discriminating between group I (insulin) and group II (SU/DPPIVi) was 1.457 (AUC 0.763, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.67-0.86) with 92.6% sensitivity and 60.0% specificity; between group II (SU/ DPPIVi) and group III (Met/TZD) was 2.870 (AUC 0.634, 95% CI 0.58-0.69) with 75.5% sensitivity and 51.4% specificity; between group III (Met/TZD) and group IV (D&E) was 3.790 (AUC 0.593, 95% CI 0.53-0.66) with 69.5% sensitivity and 49.1% specificity (Figure 3 and Supplementary Table 1).
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In the validation set (the remaining 30% of the participants), the sensitivity and specificity of PCGR cut-off value were 81.0% and 41.7% between group I (insulin) and group II (SU/DPPIVi), 73.9% and 44.4% between group II (SU/DPPIVi) and group III (Met/TZD), and 70.5% and 52.2% between group III (Met/ TZD) and group IV (D&E), respectively.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups
Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: However, the interpretation of insulin concentrations is complicated, because insulin levels should be not only matched with glucose concentrations, but also borne in mind in the situation of insulin use.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Although HOMA is often used in large clinical and epidemiological studies, it is not suitable for some diabetic patients because of hyperglycemic state or  insulin use.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In addition, a recent study measuring b-cell area in humans showed that there was no relationship between HOMA-b and b-cell area 11 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Postprandial insulin deficiency is regarded as the main explanatory factor of deteriorating glucose control in newly developed type 2 diabetes 21 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: A study showed that the reduction of postprandial insulin secretion is more prominent than that of fasting insulin secretion in the progression of type 2 diabetes 22 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: It was thus suggested that postprandial b-cell function might be a more important factor for glycemic control than fasting b-cell function.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Although there are many studies on indices for insulin secretory function, only a few studies have investigated staged management of type 2 diabetes based on insulin secretory function using these indices.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Furthermore, the studies were only able to distinguish which patients require insulin therapy based on the indices 23,24 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Recently, PCGR after oral glucose ingestion was suggested to be a better predictor for the b-cell area, the region responsible for bcell function, than fasting measures 11 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Therefore, we used a new, expanded practical index, PCGR, for assessing insulin secretion as part of a new therapeutic strategy for individualized treatment for type 2 diabetes.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: To precisely analyze the relationship between endogenous insulin secretion and the various markers, we carried out a standardized mixed meal test in newly diagnosed, drug-na€ ıve type 2 diabetic patients.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: PCGR values were correlated with other insulin secretory indices, such as HOMA-b, IGI and ICI (Table 2).
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Additionally, PCGR showed a strong correlation with glycemic indices including plasma glucose level and glycated index for glycemic control (HbA1c and GA) than HOMAb (Figure 1).
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: These results suggest that PCGR might be used as an index for insulin secretion in practical fields.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In addition, PCGR is easily calculated using postprandial C-peptide and glucose levels measured at the time of diagnosis for type 2 diabetic patients.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In the present study, we categorized diabetic patients with good glycemic control based on their maintained antidiabetic medication.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 2, PCGR levels after adjusting for age, sex, BMI and duration of disease were different according to the medication group (2.27 -0.28, 3.32 -0.11, 3.89 -0.13, 4.53 -0.14 for group I (insulin), group II (SU/ DPPIVi), group III (Met/TZD) and group IV (D&E), respectively, P < 0.001 for ANCOVA).
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: We also obtained the cut-off values of PCGR to distinguish each treatment group in patients with well-controlled glycemic level from the training set and verified that in the validation set.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: From the analysis of the training set, the cut-off values of PCGR for discriminating between treatment groups were 1.457, 2.870 and 3.790, respectively (all P < 0.001; Figure 3).
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In the validation set, the sensitivity of the PCGR cut-off value was maintained as relatively constant, although the specificity of that was low.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: We suggest that these cut-off values could be applied when choosing antidiabetic agents for patients with type 2 diabetes.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In accordance with the present results, recent studies have shown that PCGR is also a better predictor of future insulin therapy than fasting C-peptide index 25,26 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: PCGR is a simple and practical marker for insulin secretion, and it can be helpful in determining appropriate treatment modalities, such as insulin, insulin secretagogues (SU and/or DPPIVi), insulin sensitizer (Met and/or TZD) and lifestyle modification.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: As plasma glucose is the most potent stimulator of insulin secretion, it is presumed that PCGR level reflects b-cell function more precisely than FCGR or plasma Cpeptide level itself does.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Furthermore, insulin secretion is more impaired in the postprandial state than in the fasting state 7 , and it is stimulated by high plasma glucose level and incretin hormone 27 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Thus, PCGR index might be a more useful predictor of b-cell function than other indices measured during the fasting state.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: The limitations of the present study were as follows.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: First, the study was based on retrospective analysis.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Based on the results from the present study, a prospective study is in progress.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Second, we did not examine glucagon-stimulated C-peptide levels, which is one of the most widely used methods for insulin secretory functions of diabetic patients 28,29 .
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In addition, the C-peptide levels could have been influenced or modified by the medications in the second step analysis.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: For instance, prolonged treatment with sulfonylurea could have reduced C-peptide, whereas prolonged treatment with TZD could have increased b-cell mass.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: For this reason, a prospective study of drug-na€ ıve patients is in progress, based on PCGR value.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Third, we did not include meglitinide in the present study, although we suggest the use of similar cut-off values of PCGR as in group II (SU/DPPIVi), especially for patients with high postprandial glucose.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Fourth, we could not separately assess the additional effects of insulin sensitizer (Met or TZD) in group I (insulin) or group II (SU/DPPIVi), although 76.4% of patients in the present study had already been treated with additional insulin sensitizers, such as Met or TZD.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Finally, the different cut-off values of PCGR should be investigated in different ethnic populations.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Despite these limitations, we were able to differentiate treatment modalities of well-controlled type 2 diabetic patients with PCGR, and this value can be a useful marker in the determination of antidiabetic therapy.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: In conclusion, the PCGR index might be used as a marker of insulin secretion and be used as an ancillary parameter for selecting antidiabetic medication, as well as insulin therapy in type 2 diabetic patients, based on their individual b-cell functions.
body_text.section: Cut-off Values of PCGR for Discriminating Antidiabetic Medication groups

body_text.text: Further prospective study will be warranted to assess the usefulness of the PCGR index for staged diabetic management.
